articles.headline: A Global Chill in Commodity Demand Hits America’s Heartland
articles.snippet: In China and other emerging markets, growth is waning and demand for the raw materials that drive the global economy has dried up.
articles.abstract: In China and other emerging markets, growth is waning and demand for the raw materials that drive the global economy has dried up.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRANITE CITY, Ill. — A thousand miles south of this gritty steel town on the Mississippi River, West Texas oil rigs have shuddered to a halt. Seven hundred miles north, mines in the Iron Range of Minnesota have been stilled.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Earnings Misstatements Come in Bunches, Study Says
articles.snippet: The study also found that when companies playing accounting charades run into trouble, their corporate peers are deterred from mimicking their conduct.
articles.abstract: The study also found that when companies playing accounting charades run into trouble, their corporate peers are deterred from mimicking their conduct.
articles.lead_paragraph: One bad corporate apple, it seems, can spoil a whole bunch.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: Indian Tribes Look Beyond Casinos for Income
articles.snippet: As gambling revenue growth slows, tribes form enterprises in other sectors as varied as food production and private equity groups.
articles.abstract: As gambling revenue growth slows, tribes form enterprises in other sectors as varied as food production and private equity groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS, Mich. — For now, the field isn’t much. All that stands along a quiet country road is a small storage building, beyond which rolls 28 acres of prairie a mile south of this blink-and-miss-it hamlet. To Mon-ee Zapata, though, this land is both the past and the future.
articles.byline: By Steve Friess

articles.headline: F.B.I. Chief Links Scrutiny of Police With Rise in Violent Crime
articles.snippet: James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director, said he had a “strong sense” that scrutiny of the police has made officers less aggressive and emboldened criminals.
articles.abstract: James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director, said he had a “strong sense” that scrutiny of the police has made officers less aggressive and emboldened criminals.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, said on Friday that the additional scrutiny and criticism of police officers in the wake of highly publicized episodes of police brutality may have led to an increase in violent crime in some cities as officers have become less aggressive.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Pandora Shares Plummet as Competition Grows
articles.snippet: Shares in Pandora, the Internet radio service, fell by 35 percent, a plunge that was to some degree a judgment on the company’s outlook in an increasingly crowded field that now includes Apple Music.
articles.abstract: Shares in Pandora, the Internet radio service, fell by 35 percent, a plunge that was to some degree a judgment on the company’s outlook in an increasingly crowded field that now includes Apple Music.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Apple revealed this week that its new streaming service, Apple Music, had 6.5 million paying users, industry commentators debated whether that was a healthy or disappointing result for a company with such a giant reach.
articles.byline: By Ben Sisario

articles.headline: Uber Said to Plan Another $1 Billion in Fund-Raising
articles.snippet: Just three months after a new funding round valued the company at more than $50 billion, Uber is said to be going back to the well.
articles.abstract: Just three months after a new funding round valued the company at more than $50 billion, Uber is said to be going back to the well.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just three months after raising an enormous sum of money from investors, Uber is at it again.
articles.byline: By Leslie Picker and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Directors Say Volkswagen Delayed Informing Them of Trickery
articles.snippet: Senior Volkswagen board members say they learned of the company’s emissions scandal not from executives—but from news reports.
articles.abstract: Senior Volkswagen board members say they learned of the company’s emissions scandal not from executives—but from news reports.
articles.lead_paragraph: At least three members of Volkswagen’s board said they were left in the dark about the company’s emissions cheating for two weeks after top executives admitted the deception to American environmental officials.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Bush Cuts Costs, Carson Eclipses Trump in Iowa and G.O.P. Frets
articles.snippet: Party strategists and voters fear a protracted nomination fight that could end with a damaged standard-bearer facing a more unified left.
articles.abstract: Party strategists and voters fear a protracted nomination fight that could end with a damaged standard-bearer facing a more unified left.
articles.lead_paragraph: A beleaguered Jeb Bush slashed his campaign spending. Donald J. Trump lost his lead in Iowa. And a surging Ben Carson galvanized his support among social conservatives.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: The 57-Year-Old Chart That Is Dividing the Fed
articles.snippet: If you believe in the traditional Phillips curve, as some at the Fed do, inflation should be taking off any day now.
articles.abstract: If you believe in the traditional Phillips curve, as some at the Fed do, inflation should be taking off any day now.
articles.lead_paragraph: Next week, when Federal Reserve officials meet to decide whether to raise interest rates for the first time in nine years, one question will be front and center: How much faith should be placed in a line on a graph first drawn by a New Zealand economist nearly six decades ago, based on data on wages and employment in Britain dating to the 1860s?
articles.byline: By Neil Irwin

articles.headline: The Disproportionate Risks of Driving While Black
articles.snippet: An examination of traffic stops and arrests in Greensboro, N.C., uncovered wide racial differences in measure after measure of police conduct.
articles.abstract: An examination of traffic stops and arrests in Greensboro, N.C., uncovered wide racial differences in measure after measure of police conduct.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Rufus Scales, 26 and black, was driving his younger brother Devin to his hair-cutting class in this genteel, leafy city when they heard the siren’s whoop and saw the blue light in the rearview mirror of their black pickup. Two police officers pulled them over for minor infractions that included expired plates and failing to hang a flag from a load of scrap metal in the pickup’s bed. But what happened next was nothing like a routine traffic stop.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: Mexico Spared Major Damage by Giant Storm
articles.snippet: President Enrique Peña Nieto said there were no initial reports of deaths but the danger was not past. “We still can’t lower our guard,” he said.
articles.abstract: President Enrique Peña Nieto said there were no initial reports of deaths but the danger was not past. “We still can’t lower our guard,” he said.
articles.lead_paragraph: CIHUATLÁN, Mexico — A day after Hurricane Patricia all but destroyed his home, Roberto García López took the unusual step of going to work.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Paulina Villegas

articles.headline: Obama Administration Calls for Limits on Testing in Schools
articles.snippet: The administration acknowledged its own role in the proliferation of tests, and urged schools to make exams less onerous and more purposeful.
articles.abstract: The administration acknowledged its own role in the proliferation of tests, and urged schools to make exams less onerous and more purposeful.
articles.lead_paragraph: Faced with mounting and bipartisan opposition to increased and often high-stakes testing in the nation’s public schools, the Obama administration declared Saturday that the push had gone too far, acknowledged its own role in the proliferation of tests, and urged schools to step back and make exams less onerous and more purposeful.
articles.byline: By Kate Zernike

articles.headline: Bush at 91: Irritated and Invigorated by ’16 Race
articles.snippet: The senior President Bush finds himself straining to understand today’s political climate. But if he is frustrated, the 91-year-old is also immersed.
articles.abstract: The senior President Bush finds himself straining to understand today’s political climate. But if he is frustrated, the 91-year-old is also immersed.
articles.lead_paragraph: He has given up his “C.S.I.” reruns, consuming campaign coverage on Fox News — intently but fretfully — when he is perched in front of the television in his Houston home.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Amid Splits, Catholic Bishops Crack Open Door on Divorce
articles.snippet: Pope Francis called this assembly to reconsider the church’s approach to marriage and family at a time when the very definition of family is changing.
articles.abstract: Pope Francis called this assembly to reconsider the church’s approach to marriage and family at a time when the very definition of family is changing.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — After a three-week global assembly on family issues that exposed their deep divisions, Roman Catholic bishops produced a consensus document on Saturday that reinforced church doctrine but appeared to give Pope Francis enough support to advance his vision of a more merciful church.
articles.byline: By Laurie Goodstein and Elisabetta Povoledo

articles.headline: Charlie Hebdo’s Recovery From Attacks Opens New Wounds for Staff
articles.snippet: In the nine months since gunmen killed 12 people at the satirical paper’s headquarters in Paris, a surge in readers and revenue has divided employees.
articles.abstract: In the nine months since gunmen killed 12 people at the satirical paper’s headquarters in Paris, a surge in readers and revenue has divided employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Days after two gunmen burst into the offices of the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo on Jan. 7, slaughtering nearly a dozen of his colleagues and friends, Laurent Sourisseau propped himself up in his hospital bed and began to draw.
articles.byline: By Nicola Clark

articles.headline: Ex-Im Bank Dispute Threatens G.E. Factory That Obama Praised
articles.snippet: G.E. plans to close an engine factory in Waukesha, Wis., that President Obama visited in 2014 and move hundreds of jobs to Canada because of the bank’s closure.
articles.abstract: G.E. plans to close an engine factory in Waukesha, Wis., that President Obama visited in 2014 and move hundreds of jobs to Canada because of the bank’s closure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WAUKESHA, Wis. — When President Obama visited General Electric’s sprawling, red brick engine factory here in January 2014, he praised it as a sign that manufacturing in America could have a promising future.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Caught Between Protesters and Israel, Palestinian Security Forces Shift Tactics
articles.snippet: Amid violent protests in the West Bank, a longtime security alliance with Israel may be redefined in the face of public anger and mistrust.
articles.abstract: Amid violent protests in the West Bank, a longtime security alliance with Israel may be redefined in the face of public anger and mistrust.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL-BIREH, West Bank — The Palestinian security officers in civilian clothes were nearly indiscernible amid the chaos of young protesters rushing to hurl rocks at Israeli soldiers and scrambling from the gunshots and tear gas they received in return.
articles.byline: By Diaa Hadid and Rami Nazzal

articles.headline: Facebook’s Internet for All Is a Tough Sell in India
articles.snippet: Facebook’s rocky experience since it brought stripped-down Internet access to India shows that good intentions and technological savvy are not enough.
articles.abstract: Facebook’s rocky experience since it brought stripped-down Internet access to India shows that good intentions and technological savvy are not enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — If Mark Zuckerberg hopes to deliver on his vision of bringing the Internet to the four billion people  who lack it, the Facebook chief will first need to make his plan more appealing to salesmen like Shoaib Khan.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Russian Ships Near Data Cables Are Too Close for U.S. Comfort
articles.snippet: Russian submarines are aggressively operating near the undersea cables that carry almost all global Internet communications, raising concerns in the U.S.
articles.abstract: Russian submarines are aggressively operating near the undersea cables that carry almost all global Internet communications, raising concerns in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russian submarines and spy ships are aggressively operating near the vital undersea cables that carry almost all global Internet communications, raising concerns among some American military and intelligence officials that the Russians might be planning to attack those lines in times of tension or conflict.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Japan’s Struggling Economy Finds ‘Abenomics’ Is Not an Easy Fix
articles.snippet: Nearly three years after Prime Minister Shinzo Abe took office, there are signs that growth is faltering again, despite Mr. Abe’s efforts to spur the economy.
articles.abstract: Nearly three years after Prime Minister Shinzo Abe took office, there are signs that growth is faltering again, despite Mr. Abe’s efforts to spur the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s economy has contracted so many times in the last few years that the meaning of recession has started to blur. If an economy is shrinking almost as often as it is growing, what does any single downturn say about its health?
articles.byline: By Jonathan Soble

articles.headline: The Offshore Game of Online Sports Betting
articles.snippet: The story of Pinnacle Sports is a case study in how bookmaking sites, illegal in the United States, manage to operate on American soil.
articles.abstract: The story of Pinnacle Sports is a case study in how bookmaking sites, illegal in the United States, manage to operate on American soil.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hard by the High Line, in a vintage industrial building with a Romanesque arch, lights flash on powerful computers in row after row of metal cabinets and cages. Power lines connect the equipment to diesel generators on the roof. Cables route data through the building to conduits beneath New York City streets.
articles.byline: By James Glanz, Agustin Armendariz and Walt Bogdanich

articles.headline: AMC Doubles Down on Scripted Series
articles.snippet: The network aims to keep a strong hold on television audiences by focusing on scripted dramas.
articles.abstract: The network aims to keep a strong hold on television audiences by focusing on scripted dramas.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We’re playing the Garden!” Charlie Collier, the president of AMC, said on a recent Friday night.
articles.byline: By John Koblin

articles.headline: Calm Manner Has Ben Carson Rising in Polls
articles.snippet: The candidate’s gentle demeanor has resonated with supporters as some recent polls show him now in the lead in the early-voting state of Iowa.
articles.abstract: The candidate’s gentle demeanor has resonated with supporters as some recent polls show him now in the lead in the early-voting state of Iowa.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMES, Iowa — Donald J. Trump, who is rarely at a loss for words, admitted “I don’t know what’s going on” when confronted by Ben Carson’s surge past him in early-voting Iowa, where Mr. Trump had led the Republican presidential field for months.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: Start-Ups Take On Challenge of Nuclear Fusion
articles.snippet: Venture capital is flowing to a group of start-ups that are pursuing the long-sought goal of making fusion power a reality.
articles.abstract: Venture capital is flowing to a group of start-ups that are pursuing the long-sought goal of making fusion power a reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: A group of start-ups is promising a new and virtually unlimited source of power, one that produces none of the gases scientists say contribute to global warming.
articles.byline: By Dino Grandoni

articles.headline: Health Care Co-op Closings Narrow Consumers’ Choices
articles.snippet: Some officials blame the government’s actions for the shuttering of some of these start-ups created under the Affordable Care Act.
articles.abstract: Some officials blame the government’s actions for the shuttering of some of these start-ups created under the Affordable Care Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: The grim announcements keep coming, picking up pace in recent weeks.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Abby Goodnough

articles.headline: The New Face of Fandango, Born in a Movie Theater
articles.snippet: Fandango, a seller of movie tickets that hopes to position itself an entertainment hub, will debut a new mascot, Miles Mouvay, a film fanatic portrayed by Kenan Thompson, on Monday.
articles.abstract: Fandango, a seller of movie tickets that hopes to position itself an entertainment hub, will debut a new mascot, Miles Mouvay, a film fanatic portrayed by Kenan Thompson, on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Move over, Flo. Make room, Most Interesting Man in the World. Here comes Miles Mouvay, an ascot-wearing, butter-scented mascot that Fandango hopes will help consumers see it as more than a ticket seller.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: As a Boss, Carly Fiorina Was a Contradictory Figure at Hewlett-Packard
articles.snippet: Employees described a day-to-day management style in which she could shower workers with affirmation but then allow some to be laid off with only a phone call.
articles.abstract: Employees described a day-to-day management style in which she could shower workers with affirmation but then allow some to be laid off with only a phone call.
articles.lead_paragraph: At Hewlett-Packard, Carly Fiorina avoided the employee cafeteria, eating lunch in her glass office despite pleas from aides to mingle with rank-and-file workers. But in what turned out to be her last week as chief executive, she attended the funeral of an HP employee’s wife, lingering at a reception afterward to console his son.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Violence in Syria Spurs a Huge Surge in Civilian Flight
articles.snippet: The escalation in fighting, along with Russian airstrikes, was fueling the kind of desperation that has propelled a growing number toward neighboring countries and to Europe.
articles.abstract: The escalation in fighting, along with Russian airstrikes, was fueling the kind of desperation that has propelled a growing number toward neighboring countries and to Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A tenuous truce in the Syrian countryside north of the city of Homs was shattered this month when Russian warplanes attacked the village of Ter Ma’aleh, killing at least a dozen people and sending most of the residents into hurried exile.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and Maher Samaan

articles.headline: Ex-Goldman Banker and Fed Employee Will Plead Guilty in Document Leak
articles.snippet: A former Goldman Sachs banker admitted his guilt in taking confidential documents from an employee at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, who also agreed to plead guilty.
articles.abstract: A former Goldman Sachs banker admitted his guilt in taking confidential documents from an employee at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, who also agreed to plead guilty.
articles.lead_paragraph: A former Goldman Sachs banker suspected of taking confidential documents from a source inside the government has agreed to plead guilty, a rare criminal action on Wall Street, where Goldman itself is facing an array of regulatory penalties over the leak.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Peter Eavis
